data.title: A Galaxy of Thoughts â€” First time watching Pinky and the Brain since...
data.meta_description: First time watching Pinky and the Brain since childhood!I watched Pinky and the Brain as a kid (before I had even heard of Animaniacs), but not much and for years I barely remembered anything about it...
data.text:
Iâ€™ve already ranked the characters in a few tier lists, but after the release of season 2 Iâ€™ve changed my mind about a few characters in terms of ranking order, plus I just wanted to gush about my favs!

(Just a heads upâ€¦this is gonna be a long one.)

10-Julia

Julia 100% would be higher if she were in more than 2 episodes as of the time of writing, but she isnâ€™t so she lacks the depth others on the list have.

She was already sweet in her debut, but what ultimately got her here is how she stole the show in â€œReichenbrain Fallsâ€. She went from being kind, considerate, hardworking yet somewhat reserved to being an over-enthusiastic, crazy genius out for revenge.

Honestly, I believe that she wants to take over the world not necessarily because sheâ€™s interested in ruling the world, but more because of sunk-cost fallacy (she was really close to succeeding before Brain tried to mind-control her, plus her exact words were â€œâ€¦because I deserve to rule the world!â€) and because it would be the perfect way to get revenge on Brain.

What helps her stay likeable is that her wanting revenge is justified, what Brain did to her was wrong.

Sheâ€™s also really funny to watch-sheâ€™s kind of like Brain and Pinky combined (Brainâ€™s intelligence with Pinkyâ€™s insanity), and serves as a lasting consequence of Brainâ€™s actions. Whatever him and Pinky get up to is usually swept under the rug by the end of an episode as they return to the lab for tomorrow night, but not this time.

Iâ€™m glad theyâ€™re not implying she still has feelings for Brain or that he might have feelings for her (so far, at leastâ€¦please keep it up). Enemies to Lovers (or is it Lovers to Enemies to Lovers in this case?) has been done really badly inâ€¦certain franchises recently so Iâ€™m glad theyâ€™re not doing that here.

Plus, Juliaâ€™s leitmotif is an inverted version of the Pinky and the Brain theme song-thatâ€™s just cool!

9-Dr Scratchansniff

Up next is Scratchy!

What I like about Dr Scratchansniff is that due to his heavy accent, he couldâ€™ve easily been made a weirdo and have his whole character be â€œhaha foreigners and their funny sounding accents, arenâ€™t they weird?â€ it was the 90â€™s, they probably couldâ€™ve gotten away with it. Instead (thankfully) in most episodes the opposite is true. Heâ€™s usually the straight man to other characterâ€™s antics, be it the Warners, Mr Plotz, etc.

He also has a really nice â€œarcâ€ (I use that term loosely) about warming up to the Warners. He goes from wanting to avoid them as much as possible (he even threatened to turn them into stew in The Monkey Song), to actually getting along with them pretty well, to essentially becoming their dad. I think itâ€™s sweet! Most people point to â€œIâ€™m Madâ€ being the moment that established his â€œdad statusâ€ by taking the Warners to a Circus, but what sold it for me was actually the segment â€œFakeâ€, where the Warners agree to come with Scratchy to a wrestling match, even though they know itâ€™s fake and didnâ€™t want to be there. He didnâ€™t force them, they agreed to go seemingly just to make him happy. I canâ€™t imagine the Warners purposefully choosing not to have fun for anyone other than someone they considered family.

Although season 4 and 5 of the original show kind of ruin it (their dynamic in â€œAnchors Awarnersâ€ is extremely simplified and then in season 5 the Warners barely interact with Scratchy)â€¦but letâ€™s not talk about that, look at Scratchy tuck the Warners into bed!

Adorable!

8-Rita

Sheâ€™s not talked about all that much, but Rita actually has some depth to her character. Not to mention her segments had a lot of heart.

In â€œWhen Rita met Runtâ€ we find out she was made cynical and world-weary due to neglect. She tries to tell herself she hates humans and just wants their food, but deep down she really just wants a good home with a loving owner. She tries to be independent and not get attached to Runt at first, but she does anyway and by â€œPuttinâ€™ on the Blitzâ€ she proves to be fiercely loyal (and tough too) by giving up her chance for that loving home to save Runt.

At end of the day she really just craves love and affection, itâ€™s the main reason she considers raising the kittens in â€œSmitten with Kittensâ€, even though she knows she can barely feed herself and Runt, let alone three more people.

Her segments in the original probably had the most amount of heartfelt moments between them out of any other characterâ€™s segments, which helps her character stand out amongst the more comedic members of the cast. The only downside of this is that due to her character being taken more seriously than most on the show, sheâ€™s not all that funny. Not unfunny, but after her first episode (with snarky lines like â€œGet a kid ladyâ€) I canâ€™t recall that many times she made me laugh. Which is fine, but it IS a comedy show after all.

And she obviously has a phenomenal singing voice thanks to Bernadette Peters!

7-Nora

Nora was funny enough in season 1, but she didnâ€™t get much screen time. Her personality was established well enough-she was condescending, stern, and selfish, but she wasnâ€™t all that fleshed out, beyond being a sort of foil to the Warners. Sheâ€™s no-nonsense whereas they always mess about. What really got her on this list was how she was fleshed out in season 2.

At first I did prefer Plotz, but season 2 has developed Nora to the point where I think she has more depth as a character than Plotz does. Heâ€™s a fun character but was kinda just bossy, mean and greedy, thatâ€™s about it-his season 2 cameo was fun though.

We learn that Nora overcompensates for her lack of parenting skills by buying her daughter whatever she wants.

She has also shown more signs of being short-tempered, having more fits of rage than last season.

We also find out why sheâ€™s so competitive and obsessed with success, because of her family, mainly her great grandmother Flora Dora. Her sisters belittle her, her great grandmother not only is a very successful business woman but also constantly organizes competitions at family gatherings, itâ€™s no wonder sheâ€™s a firm believer in â€œpulling up the ladder behind herâ€.

She seems to want to live up to her great grandmotherâ€™s legacy, she does seem to genuinely look up to her. Plotz was motivated mostly by making money, whereas Nora only seems interested in money as proof of her status and how successful she is, not necessarily due to greed, otherwise she wouldnâ€™t spend millions on her daughter. This may even explain why she is very concerned about being in shape (almost every time they cut to her in her office sheâ€™s exercising).

She doesnâ€™t just want to be successful (or at least, her idea of being successful) she needs people to know it just by looking at her.

Overall, I like the direction they took with her character and I canâ€™t wait to see more from her.

6-Wakko

Surprised? I do like Wakko, but not as much as most of the fandom it seems.

He does stand out amongst the Warners though, being less reliant on witty dialogue and more on visual gags and slapstick.

One aspect of his character that I like that I donâ€™t see many people talk about is that heâ€™s a bit of a tinkerer. Moments that come to mind are when he â€œfixedâ€ the garage remote in â€œGarage Sale of the Centuryâ€, when he built a huge contraption just to use a whoopie cushion, and even one moment in the reboot where he microwaved a TV remote because he thought it would give it magical powers in â€œAnimani-yetâ€. I wonder if season 2 of the reboot establishing that he likes video games is meant to be acknowledgment of his interest in tech.

I like that all the Warners are supposed to be maniacs yet heâ€™s known as the â€œcrazy oneâ€, which a lot of his gimmicks make pretty clear (his gag bag, saying made up words like â€œfabooâ€, a weird obsession with Don Knotts, acts more animalistic than the other two Warners-often acting like a dog and is often seen letting his tongue hang out, etc).

I do like Wakko but to me heâ€™s more likeable than he isâ€¦funny? I dunno, heâ€™s not unfunny but he doesnâ€™t make me laugh as much as the next five do. Not to mention isnâ€™t that complex either, which is fine, I mean all Animaniacs characters arenâ€™t that complex to be honest, but Wakko more so than others.

Not to say that heâ€™s one-note, because heâ€™s not. In addition to being the insane â€œeating stuff guyâ€, heâ€™s also naÃ¯ve, optimistic, sincere (if not just straight up blunt at times), and kind-hearted, even though he can be emotionally volatile. Thereâ€™s no doubt in my mind the show wouldnâ€™t be the same without him.

5-Slappy

She may be ranked 5th highest, but if weâ€™re talking purely on a comedic standpoint Slappyâ€™s probably one of the funniest characters in the franchise. Part of the reason why is becauseâ€¦wellâ€¦sheâ€™s awful.

Sheâ€™s lazy. Sheâ€™s cranky. Sheâ€™s vindictive. Sheâ€™s bitter. Sheâ€™s violent and borderline sadistic. Sheâ€™s also aware of all that and doesnâ€™t wish to change.

Sheâ€™s where a lot of the showâ€™s cynical edge to its humour comes from. What helps is that for all her flaws, itâ€™s not like she actively tries to cause trouble. She just wants to be left alone most of the time. But, like what often happens to the Warners, someone just has to swoop in and act like a jerk. And when someone tries to mess with Slappy, she holds nothing back. Itâ€™s almost admirableâ€¦almost.

Remember when she bombed a criticâ€™s house because he didnâ€™t find her funny (and expressed disappointment when she found out he WASNâ€™T inside his house when she did)? Or when she threatened to blow up a jury (of biased wolves, to be fair) unless they voted her not-guilty on a crime she technically did commitâ€¦and then blew them up anyway?

Again, sheâ€™s no role model. She does what she does because she thinks itâ€™s funny-and it is!

Although I do like the scene in â€œThe Sound of Warnersâ€ that shows that whilst the Warners only use force against people who deliberately wronged them, Slappy will just bomb anyone who she finds annoying, whether they meant it or not. Stuff like that makes her bond with Skippy all the more adorable, because you know how mean she can be to almost everyone else. Yet she genuinely does a pretty good job raising Skippy. They get along pretty much all the time, she does her best to keep him happy (in â€œBumbieâ€™s Momâ€ she flew across the country in a plane just so heâ€™d stop crying over a movie, for example), she even tries to teach him lessons sometimes-although sometimes regrets it because it makes her â€œsound like an after school specialâ€.

Sheâ€™s a veteran toon who knows every trick in the book, often deconstructing gags and can beat her foes without breaking a sweat-now thatâ€™s comedy!

4-Brain

Slappy has the edge when it come to comedy, but Brain is a bit more complex in terms of character and still makes me laugh. Slappy is funny but ultimately is a simple character.

Whilst Brain is very monotone in the early episodes, overtime he develops to become a lot more expressive, megalomaniacal, grouchy and sympathetic.

I admire his perseverance-the guy never gives up. He doesnâ€™t let the fact that he is a tiny lab mouse stop him from trying to take over the world, despite the fact that he has failed over and over again. Now, is this a good goal to have? No. Are his methods always morally sound? No. But you just canâ€™t help but root for him. Even though a lot of his plans are ridiculous, and even though Pinky tends to get blamed for them going wrong (and admittedly a lot of the time it is his fault) Brains screws up his own plans just as much. But I kinda like that? Brainâ€™s smart but heâ€™s not necessarily wise, if you get what I mean.

Brainâ€™s been given multiple backstories, but each one reveals he basically only wants to take over the world because he feels unsafe and fears not being in control for fear of it leading to him getting hurt. They also seem to have affected how willing he is to be open about his feelings or his affection for others (mainly Pinky). He tries to gain control of the world as a way of seeking comfort over what happened to him, be it him being taken from his home or being experimented on the the point where it physically damaged his tail. He also seems to genuinely believe heâ€™d make the world a better place.

Then thereâ€™s his bond with Pinky, which isâ€¦â€œcomplicatedâ€? He does insult and bop him, but we know at this point he does consider him his best friend, he just struggles with being open about it. There have been multiple times when it seemed like he might lose Pinky forever, and each time he gets upset about it, sometimes to the point of crying. Not to mention he always makes sure his plans involve Pinky in some way, when he could probably come up with a plan that he could do completely by himself if he really wanted to.

The segment Future Brain even shows that he literally trusts Pinky more than he trusts himself. Thatâ€™s actually really sweet.

3-Pinky

I genuinely think Pinky is probably the nicest character on the show (although letâ€™s be honest, the bar isnâ€™tâ€¦all that high) considering he never really wants to fight or hurt anyone. He just wants to get along with everybody. In fact itâ€™s the main reason reason I ranked him higher than Brain. Not to blame Brain for being world-weary; given his trauma I get why he resorts to doing some of the things he does, but I just think Pinkyâ€™s acts of kindness are touching. The usually emotionally constipated Brain even said once that Pinky is â€œpure of heartâ€â€¦before insulting his intelligence(or I guess lack thereof), but still.

His endless loyalty and love for Brain is so endearing. His tendency to put Brainâ€™s wants above his own, like when he dedicated what was supposed to be his Christmas list to asking for something Brain wants, because he knows how much it means to Brain, or when he pushed aside his own birthday (the ONE day of the year he gets to call the shots) just so Brain could focus on taking over the world, is somewhat admirable but also kind of sad. In a good way.

Not that he lacks agency or his own wants/priorities. Heâ€™s shown interest in make up, fashion, cooking, cheese (of course), whatever the latest most popular genre of music is (be it country or pop), etc. I think him spending so much time watching TV is what led to him being very interested in pop culture, and that in turn has led to him being more of a people person than Brain (which I guess isnâ€™t too hard to achieve). Pinky tends to get along with strangers quite well and very quickly most of the time, which has come in handy for a lot of Brainâ€™s plans.

Also, thanks to the â€œAre you pondering what Iâ€™m pondering?â€ gag, he gets really bizarre dialogue a lot of the time, so bizarre you canâ€™t help but laugh. Not to mention the times he just resorts to saying made up words.

Another reason Pinky is so high is because right out the gate he proved to be an entertaining character. Brain took a while to become an engaging character, but Pinky always had fun quirks, even before his later developments. We find out pretty soon heâ€™s a TV addict, has a funny British accent, is cheerful, spontaneously yells made up words , and is really, REALLY stupid. Slappy excels at comedy, but Brain has more depth as a character, and Pinky is a good middle ground between those two things.

2-Dot

Can I talk about her design first? She is the cute one after all. I appreciate that, unlike a lot of female character designs for animals (particularly older designs, from the 1920â€™s all the way to the 90â€™s), sheâ€™s not just the main male lead turned pink or with a bow on-for example, she has no whiskers, unlike Yakko or Wakko (those arenâ€™t whiskers, thatâ€™s her hair). She also isnâ€™t unnecessarily given human anatomy or human-looking hair. She isnâ€™t permanently given eyelashes to make it obvious that sheâ€™s a girl-sheâ€™s only drawn with eyelashes when sheâ€™s purposely trying to look cute for the camera, as seen below. Otherwise sheâ€™ll just have dot eyes, just like her brothers. This post will give you a better idea of what I mean.

In fact she probably has the best design of the Warners. Not only is she, wellâ€¦CUTE, her pink skirt and flower help her look feminine and stylish, but without over-doing it with the cuteness by giving her a more covered up/conservative (conservative as in traditional, not in a political context) look . Her brothersâ€™ designs donâ€™t really say anything about their personalities (if you didnâ€™t know who Yakko and Wakko were, what about their designs would indicate that Yakko likes to talk? Or that Wakko likes to eat?) Her outfit is also the best homage to classic characters from the 1920â€™s/30â€™s.

Yakko would be more accurate if he was wearing shorts, and Wakkoâ€™s backwards cap screams the 90â€™s.

Fun fact! Dotâ€™s original concept art design kinda resembles Minnieâ€™s modern look (although given when it was drawn, this was of course unintentional)

Now on to her personality, Dot has a lot of good dialogue, although some lines make me laugh specifically because of Tress Macneilleâ€™s delivery. Dot often uses cuteness to get out of danger or to give foes a false sense of security, so itâ€™s all the more surprising when she roars at them or bludgeons them with a mace. Itâ€™s sneaky and itâ€™s cool to see how she takes what many might see as a weakness (being small and dainty) and make it her strength.

And given that she was created in the 90â€™s, I appreciate that sheâ€™s actually allowed to be witty and funny and wacky and isnâ€™t just eye candy or the damsel in distress, or the love interest (although since sheâ€™s the little sister this was a given), or the no nonsense one. She has a very fleshed out personality. Sheâ€™s acerbic, short-tempered, extremely confident in herself, competitive, violent, and LOVES getting attention. Obviously sheâ€™s not the first good animated female character, but legitimately well written animated female leads who didnâ€™t have sexist tropes tied to their characters were rarer back in the day.

Whilst I do applaud the original series for how it handled Dotâ€™s cuteness, I do like how the reboot has shown how she can stand out amongst the Warners beyond being the â€œcute oneâ€. Letâ€™s be honest, in the original series her other defining traits were taken to the extreme by one of her brothers; her brothers got to be the best at multiple things whilst she only got one main thing (Honestly I also personally think the original series kinda underutilised her in general compared to her brothers). Yeah she was smart but Yakko was the smartest. Yeah she could be violent but Wakko was more destructive. So what was left for Dot to be the best at? Being cuteâ€¦and thatâ€™s about it. So itâ€™s great to see that in the reboot many episodes have emphasized that she does excel in at least one other area beyond being cute-determination. Segments like Rug of War, Warnerâ€™s Ark, The Warnerâ€™s Vault, Suffragette City, etc really show off her spunk and how passionate she can be, even more so than her brothers.

1-Yakko

No change here, Yakkoâ€™s still my favourite! He has a lot of traits I find entertaining; heâ€™s a wise-guy, a know it all, a good big brother, crafty, and actually pretty laid back when not purposefully playing up the zaniness. His snarky remarks are always great, they always seem to save the best dialogue for him. I like that the reboot emphasized just how much he likes to sing. He always did, all the Warners do, but Yakko in particular seems almost obsessed with it. It makes sense, he is the one who yaks, plus it makes for a funny running gag.

He also tends to try and turn things into a comedy bit. Heâ€™s shocked about a new revelation? He grabs a drink just so he can do a spit take. They lack a map? He pretends to have one and claims itâ€™s improv. Heâ€™s definitely dedicated to being â€œthe funny guyâ€.

One thing I find funny about him is that he can get weirdly petty about things (specifically needing lukewarm tea, insisting his slacks are smoky topaz not tan, considering wearing a coat as some sort of sacrifice, etc)

itâ€™s also nice to see a male lead in a cartoon comedy that isnâ€™t either optimistic, upbeat and wacky-but dumb, or they are smart but are either cynical, grouchy and/or mean, or theyâ€™re the â€œloserâ€ nerd who gets made fun of every other episode. Heck, those descriptions fit some characters within Animaniacs itself! But not with Yakko, turns out male leads can be energetic AND smart without being made fun of for it! Who wouldâ€™ve thought? Obviously, again, NOT the first time this has happened in a cartoon (Sokka, for example), but I find that a lot of male main characters (Iâ€™m talking specifically about animated comedies here, not fiction in general) fall under one of those three categories.

And unlike his siblings, who will often resort to violence/slapstick to best an opponent, Yakko (usually) just solves his problems verbally, which I find a little more engaging to watch. â€œMorning Malaiseâ€, â€œRome Sweet Romeâ€ and the song â€œBe Like Meâ€ are some good examples of this.

â€œFear and Laughter in Burbankâ€ I would argue improves his character, confirming that he hates being alone, fears not being funny/losing his voice and seems to seek validation, via either his jokes or his singing. Hence why he references Yakkoâ€™s World a lot, itâ€™s a crowd pleaser. Itâ€™s his go-to to get someone to like him, like in â€œSweet and Sour Sixteenâ€ when he tries to calm the crowd, and in â€œYakko Amakkoâ€ when he tries to win the animator over by singing it. Itâ€™s endearing to see a more anxious side to a character who otherwise doesnâ€™t take things too seriously.

.

.

.

Alright, thatâ€™s all I got! This might be my longest post ever but it was really fun to write. Who are your favourite Animaniacs characters?

Iâ€™m going to list a few things I think the reboot does better than the original show so far (not including technical things like animation quality or sound quality, thatâ€™s not a fair comparison). Here we go:

1. Thereâ€™s a â€œHereâ€™s the showâ€™s nameyâ€ variant every episode now rather than re-used lines (like â€œPinky and the Brain-yâ€). I totally get why the original show re-used lines (although by season 3 they do so way less), but itâ€™s just really cool the a new and unique one every episode now.

2. Yakkoâ€™s role as big brother seems more apparent now. He was always the leader in the original show sure, and he clearly did care for his siblings, but there wasnâ€™t really a sense of authority there. The Warners, either alone or together, always did their own thing. The fact that they werenâ€™t all (physically) the same age didnâ€™t really matter in most episodes, and often only apparent due to their (kind of inconsistent in the original-I SAID I WOULDNâ€™T TALK ABOUT THE ANIMATION) height differences. Now, in addition to him being the leader, thereâ€™s multiple episodes where Dot/Wakko will ask Yakko for permission to do stuff, like keeping the bunnies as pets or to watch TV.

Itâ€™s a cute touch, a nice little reminder that â€œOh yeah theyâ€™re not tripletsâ€.

3. The PG rating has allowed for edgier jokes/language. Characters can say â€œHellâ€ now, Pinky almost said â€œbull-(you know what)â€ and Wakko almost said â€œmotherf-(you know what)â€, then thereâ€™s these:

Itâ€™s dark but I think itâ€™s funny darn it ğŸ¤£.

4. Less mediocre segments. Iâ€™ve said it before, Iâ€™ll say it again, the Warners, Pinky and the Brain and Slappy carried the original show. I also enjoyed Rita and Runt and Minerva Mink segments, but they were cut from the show after season 1, so that sucks. Every other segment on the show I consider kinda okay/mediocre/bad ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸. A lot of characters wouldâ€™ve worked better as recurring characters within segments where theyâ€™re not the stars. Honestly their absence is a positive in my book, while watching the original show I often found myself thinking â€œMan I wish this show only had the Warners, Pinky and the Brain and Slappy segments in itâ€. I know Slappy isnâ€™t in the reboot but thatâ€™s not a deal breaker for me (the other two segments are a lot more popular so I understand prioritising them). If no Slappy also means no Katie Kaboom, Iâ€™m good.

5. More heartfelt moments - outside of the Rita and Runt segments (as in thereâ€™s a higher ratio of them, not trying to compare how heartfelt they are). In the original, pretty much the only segments that had heartfelt moments consistently was Rita and Runt (Ritaâ€™s song about humans, â€œSmitten with Kitttensâ€, â€œPuttinâ€™ on the Blitzâ€, etc). This is fine, itâ€™s a comedy show; but it would have been nice if some of the characters that got a lot more screen time than those two (the Warners, Pinky and the Brain, etc) had some too, especially since there are no Rita and Runt segments past season 1 anyway.

I know before the reboot there were quite a quite few heartfelt moments related to Animaniacs-the climax of the Pinky and the Brain Christmas special, Dotâ€™s fake out death (spoilers for a movie from over two decades ago-yes itâ€™s that old get over it) in Wakkoâ€™s Wishâ€¦basically all of â€œOne Flew Over the Cuckoo Clockâ€. But most of those arenâ€™t actually in the original show, only one of them is. Wakkoâ€™s Wish is a non-canon (I swear â€œAnimaniacsâ€ and â€œcanonâ€ are two words that donâ€™t mix but you get my point) movie and Pinky and the Brain series is a spin-off. If weâ€™re talking exclusively about the original series that ran from 1993 to 1998, then only â€œOne Flew Over the Cuckoo Clockâ€ counts really.

Maaaaaybe that one moment in Taming of the Screwy when Scratchy tells the Warners to leaveâ€¦but it was really quick and not taken that seriously (it kinda just felt like build up for a punchline) so I think that oneâ€™s a stretch (although it was a little sad).

Meanwhile the reboot already has caught up to it (in only 13 episodes as well) with two moments; Brainâ€™s backstory in â€œRoadent Tripâ€ and Yakkoâ€™s panic attack in â€œFear and Laughter in Burbankâ€. Theyâ€™re both taken seriously, last over a minute and say something pretty interesting about the characters involved. Itâ€™s just nice to see characters other than Rita and Runt be allowed to have emotional moments (again, within the actual show). Itâ€™s on-par with the original in this regard despite having 86 less episodes. And thereâ€™s probably more heartfelt moments to come!

6. The Warnerâ€™s fangs:

They make them look a little more feral! ğŸ˜ Very fitting, I wish they had them originally now. I also appreciate that they (usually) donâ€™t have gaps in their teeth anymore. Donâ€™t get me wrong, I LOVE their TMS designs, but I honestly prefer the Warners with no gaps in their teeth.

7. The PatB segments. Just in general, overall I like them more than in the original show (Iâ€™m comparing them to the ones in the original Animaniacs, Iâ€™m not talking about the PatB segments in the spin off series, Pinky an the Brain). Not only are they more creative, with ideas like Future Brain and Julia, they also do the running gag thing less. What I mean is, in the original show their segments sometimes would have a running gag they do over and over within a segment, to the point where it becomes obvious that gag is how/related to how the plan is gonna fail. Some examples of segments that do this are â€œBubba Bo Bob Brainâ€, â€œSpellboundâ€ and â€œBrain Meets Brawnâ€. Now of course we know theyâ€™re gonna fail, but trying to guess how they fail or the surprise how how they fail is one of the fun parts of their segments. Their segments are already quite formulaic, so why add to that? The reboot so far pretty much only did this once in â€œClose Encounters of the Worst Kindâ€, so thatâ€™s good.

8. More variety in terms of musical genres. Most of the songs in the old show are of the old-school Broadway type of music. Thereâ€™s a lot of orchestral music, a bit of jazz. Many songs just add lyrics to pre-existing music. Which is good, â€˜cause those songs are good. But I appreciate the reboot adding some other genres in there, like pop and hip hop. Theyâ€™re NOT what youâ€™d expect an Animaniacs song to sound like, but theyâ€™re still amazing! (like The Cutening song or Yakkoâ€™s rap).

9. The Warnersâ€™ morality. This oneâ€™s really important. Ideally, the Warners should act like karmic tricksters. Yeah they can be annoying to anybody, but are generally harmless and actually pretty friendly if left alone/arenâ€™t being mistreated. Once someone actually provokes them though, they wonâ€™t hesitate to humiliate, harm and drive insane their â€œspecial friendâ€. This is explained well in â€œThe Sound of Warnersâ€ (credit goes to clownmoontoon for the video):

https://va.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_qnxp2bDmlE1r1jfup.mp4

Sometimes the Warners donâ€™t even need to be the ones being provoked for them to go after someone for being a jerk, like in â€œMorning Malaiseâ€, where they call out a radio show host for being rude to their guests, or in â€œDotâ€™s Entertainmentâ€, where they call out a parody of Andrew Lloyd Webber for placing blame onto his actors.

But then in seasons 4 and 5 of the original show they start bothering people and legitimately harming people who literally werenâ€™t being rude to them at all. Some examples of this are â€œAnchors Awarnersâ€, â€œAcquaintancesâ€, and â€œBack in Styleâ€:

I guess I can understand in â€œBack in Styleâ€, they were mad about being sold off to other studios against their will, but they took it out on actors who probably had no say in the matter.

Thankfully, in the reboot they seem back to normal, once again only intentionally humiliating and/or harming people who actually provoked them, be it hunters (â€œGood Warner Huntingâ€,) cocky athletes, (â€œGold Meddlersâ€), rude conductors (â€œHere Comes Trebleâ€), etc.

â€¦and I think thatâ€™s all I got. There are other things too but theyâ€™re smaller points not really worth mentioning. I do like both series the same but wanted to praise the reboot specifically given that I have done multiple posts analysing the original show.
